context: Externally, Orthodox Jews can be identified by their <b5_0>manner of dress<b5_0/> and family lifestyle. <b6_0>Orthodox women<b6_0/> dress modestly by keeping most of their skin <a0_0>covered<a0_0/>. Additionally, married women cover their <a1_0>hair<a1_0/>, most commonly in the form of a <b7_0>scarf<b7_0/>, also in the form of hats, bandanas, berets, snoods or, sometimes, wigs. Orthodox men wear a <b8_0>skullcap<b8_0/> known as a <a2_0>kipa<a2_0/> and often fringes called "<a3_0>tzitzit<a3_0/>". <a4_0>Haredi<a4_0/> men often grow beards and always wear black <b9_0>hats and suits<b9_0/>, indoors and outdoors. However, Modern Orthodox Jews are commonly indistinguishable in their dress from those around them.
